div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, February 14, 1901
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders
Vol 1 - 1901

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, February 14, 1901.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following-
named noncommissioned staff officers of the artillery regiments
are hereby transferred to the Artillery Corps, and appointed
sergeants major, senior grade, therein, to date from February
2, 1901:

Michael J. Moore, sergeant major;
Thomas Clark, regimental quartermaster sergeant.
John L. Sommers, regimental quartermaster sergeant.
George W. Harvey, regimental quartermaster sergeant.
Edward C. England, regimental quartermaster sergeant.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Recruit Ross Tate,
general service, now in the hands of the civil authorities serv-
ing sentence of imprisonment, will be discharged without
honor from the Army by the officer in charge of the recruit-
ing station, No. 951 Penn avenue, Pittsburg, Pennsylvania.
This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay.

ment of California, for duty as chief surgeon of that depart-
ment. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

11. By direction of the Secretary of War, Acting Assistant
Surgeon John J. Gilhuley, U. S. Army, will proceed from
Bridgeport, Connecticut, to Governors Island, New York, and
report in person to the commanding general, Department of
the East, for assignment to temporary duty. The travel en-
joined is necessary for the public service.

12. The following order has been received from the War
Department:

By direction of the President, Captain David DuB. Gaillard, Corps of
Engineers, U. S. Army, is relieved from further duty as assistant to the
engineer commissioner of the District of Columbia.

13. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Captain
David DuB. Gaillard, Corps of Engineers, U. S. Army, will
proceed to and take station at Duluth, Minnesota, and relieve
Major Daniel W. Lockwood, Corps of Engineers, U. S. Army,
of the duties formerly in charge of Major Clinton B. Sears,
Corps of Engineers, U. S. Army, together with all money and
property appertaining thereto. The travel enjoined is neces-
sary for the public service.

14. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, is detailed as a member of the
board of medical officers appointed by paragraph 1, Special
Orders. No. 28, February 2, 1901, from this office, to meet at
the Army Medical Museum Building, in this city, for the ex-
amination of candidates for admission to the Medical Corps of
the Army.
✓

15. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, Major
Richard T. Yeatman, 22d U. S. Infantry, now at Fort Schuy-
ler, New York, on leave of absence of which he availed him-
self at Fort Wayne, Michigan, will proceed to Fort Slocum,
New York, and report in person to the commanding officer for
assignment to the duty of conducting recruits from that post
to the Presidio of San Francisco, California, and upon arrival
at San Francisco will report in person to the commanding
general, Department of California, for further duty with re-
cruits. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.
